title: Challenger annuities a royal commission casualty
text:
Analyst Daniel Toohey said Challenger’s touted 5.2 per cent book growth was made up almost entirely of “lumpy, lower margin institutional sales” with just $2 million being attributed to retail book growth.

Mr Toohey also pointed out that Challenger’s retail annuities sales figures were largely dependent on the Japanese market, where sales are tracking in line with financial year targets.

“However, excluding Japan, the domestic retail business is now shrinking with Lifetime and Term annuities sales down 40 per cent on the previous corresponding period,” Mr Toohey said.

Challenger told the Australian Securities Exchange that the decline in its Australian annuities sales were driven partly by the Hayne royal commission, especially its Liquid Lifetime and CarePlus products, which saw declines of $86 million and $71 million respectively over the quarter.

"Australian annuity sales...continue to be affected by disruption in the retail financial advice market following the [royal commission]," said Challenger chief executive Richard Howes in a statement to the ASX.

"This has resulted in a significant reduction in financial adviser numbers and increased movement by advisers across licensees."

Mr Howes claimed that client remediation programs at the major wealth management houses, as well as merger and acquisition activity, had meant fewer client acquisitions for its annuity business.

Challenger's funds management arm reported funds under management of $81 billion, up $1.9 billion or 2 per cent over the quarter.

It hopes that active exchange-traded fund launches, such as the quoting and trading of its Kapstream member fund on the Chi-X exchange, will continue to see FUM grow in its funds business.
description: Challenger Limited has announced quarterly financial results well below analysts' expectations.
